title: Sentiment Analysis of Texts from Social Networks Based on Machine Learning Methods for Monitoring Public Sentiment
author: Tolebay Arsen Nurlanuly (Astana IT University), A.K. Zhumadillaeva (Astana IT University)
relevance_why: The proposed methods for sentiment analysis, especially using transformer-based models, can be beneficial in audio applications where sentiment detection is important, such as in analyzing user feedback on audio content.
background: Analyzing sentiment in social media text to gauge public mood in real-time, addressing the challenges posed by informal language and dynamic content.
contribution: This paper introduces a combined machine learning framework using traditional methods alongside transformers to enhance real-time sentiment analysis accuracy.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily relied on lexicon-based or basic supervised learning classifiers, which struggled with subtleties like sarcasm and context.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by integrating advanced transformer models (DistilBERT, RoBERTa) which offer enhanced contextual understanding and reduce misclassifications.

key_innovation: Combines traditional machine learning models with transformer architectures for a more nuanced sentiment analysis approach.
real_world_impact: The findings have implications for real-time sentiment monitoring by corporations and governments, potentially influencing policymaking and marketing strategies. This can improve engagement and response strategies based on public sentiment trends.
limitations: The performance can be hampered by computational overhead and data quality issues, particularly with domain-specific jargon.

new_terms.transformer-based architectures: **Transformer-based architectures** are deep learning models that leverage self-attention mechanisms to better understand the context in language processing tasks, providing enhancements over traditional recurrent neural networks.
new_terms.TF-IDF: **Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF)** is a statistical measure used to evaluate the importance of a word in a document relative to a collection or corpus, helping to identify salient features for text analysis.
